Westlake Longview Corporation

Located within the Sabine Industrial District of Eastman Chemical Company Texas Operations

Harrison County (near Longview), Texas  



Executive Summary 



I. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Westlake Longview Corporation (WLC) came into existence in December 2006 when Westlake Chemical Corporation purchased Eastman Chemical Company's polyethylene assets located within the Eastman Chemical Company Texas Operations (TXO) plant site near Longview, Texas.  With the sale of these and other assets within TXO, the plant site has developed into a closed access industrial park, also known as the Sabine Industrial District.  WLC's production personnel include TXO Leased Workforce operators.  



WLC is subject to safety policies and expectations of both Westlake Chemical Corporation and TXO.  The accidental release and emergency response policies of Eastman Chemical Company are summarized in its Administrative Policies.  Per WLC procedure WLC-H&S-001 General Safety Policies, all WLC employees, Leased Workforce operators, and contractors are required as a minimum to follow the TXO Authorized Safe Practice Manual (ASPM).  WLC-H&S-017 Site Emergency Plan designates how WLC will interact with the TXO comprehensive site emergency plan. 



As described in HSE Standards of Practice, "Westlake Chemical Corporation (Westlake) accepts our responsibility to protect the environment and the health and safety of our employees, their families, and the public. The protection of human health, the environment, and the management of process safety and distribution risks are core values of the corporation and will be managed as an integral part of our business. The goal of all Westlake employees is to achieve continuous and measurable improvement. This policy will be enabled through Corporate HSE policies/management systems and appropriate business or site-level policies and management plans that establish objectives and targets.

Flammable Gases and Liquids



Basic Information:

Ethylene is a colorless gas with a sweet odor.  Propane, sometimes referred to as liquefied petroleum gas, is nontoxic, colorless, and virtually odorless. Both of these materials are extremely flammable. Leaks have the potential to ignite and create a flash fire or a vapor cloud explosion.



Uses:

Ethylene is the basic building block for polyethylene plastics produced by Westlake. Polyethylene is used in many common items including toys, food containers, automobiles, and garbage bags.  Propane is used as a modifier in some polyethylene product formulations.



Ammonia, Anhydrous 



Basic Information:

Anhydrous ammonia is a clear, colorless gas with a sharp, intensely irritating odor. The vapors are irritating to the eyes and respiratory tract. Contact with the liquid can cause frostbite. Long-term exposure to low concentrations or short-term exposure to high concentrations can result in adverse health effects from inhalation. Gaseous ammonia is lighter than air, but vapors from a leak may initially hug the ground. Ammonia gas is normally not considered a serious fire hazard, but at high enough concentration and under the right conditions, it can ignite and burn. Ammonia is soluble in water, forming a corrosive liquid. 



Uses:

WLC uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant. 



Titanium Tetrachloride

Basic Information:



Titanium tetrachloride is a heavy liquid with a yellowish color and a sharp, pungent odor. It reacts with water or atmospheric moisture to produce a white cloud of titanium oxide and hydrochloric acid vapors. Long-term exposure to low concentrations of hydrochloric acid or short-term exposure to high concentrations of hydrochloric

acid may result in adverse health effects from inhalation. In high enough concentrations, the hydrochloric acid may cause severe irritation to the eyes, coughing, and breathing difficulty.



Uses:

Titanium tetrachloride, received in 250-gallon cylinders, is a raw material used in the manufacture of some polyethylene product formulations made at WLC.



III. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



WLC utilizes a "layers of protection" approach to protect people and the environment. This approach includes, but is not limited to, the following elements:



Designing for Safety

-    Storage tanks, vessels, and equipment designed and constructed to strict industry and government standards.

-    Analysis of process design and operations for safety prior to their installation, and periodically thereafter, in accordance with the requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.

-    Control systems and instruments to provide continuous monitoring of operating conditions and alarm notifications to operators of upset conditions.

-    Emergency shutdown systems that automatically shut down operations to a safe state if emergency conditions develop.

-    Automatic deluge systems that cool equipment in the event of a fire and disperse flammable or toxic vapors in the event of leaks. 

-    Combustible gas monitors installed in critical locations to sound an alarm and turn on the deluge systems in the event of leaks.

-    Remotely operated isolation valves installed in critical locations to allow quick shutdown and isolation of leaks.

-    Pressure relief devices on storage tanks and process equipment to prevent rupture.

-    Excess flow valves and check valves on ammonia storage tanks to automatically stop flow in the event of large leaks.

-    Ammonia gas detectors installed in critical locations to sound an alarm and turn on deluge systems in the event of a leak.

-    Protective caps to

cover titanium tetrachloride cylinder valves at all times when the cylinders are not in use. 

-    Operators, mechanics, and contractor personnel trained and qualified in accordance with OSHA regulations.

-    Standard written operating procedures developed and used by operations personnel.

-    A formal, written management of change (MOC) procedure is in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modifications.



Maintaining Safe Operations/Auditing Operations

-    Regular inspection of storage tanks, vessels, and equipment.

-    Numerous mechanical integrity and preventative maintenance programs to ensure equipment is in sound working condition. These include an extensive piping and equipment corrosion and vibration inspection and correction program.

-    Both internal and corporate audits conducted on a regular schedule to help ensure compliance with company safety procedures (both WLC and TXO) and regulations. 

-    OSHA periodic inspections to continue Westlake's designation as an OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) Star Site.

-    Use of the SafeStart program, which encourages employees to discuss potential risks before performing a task.

-    Implemented recommendations of a two-phase operational risk assessment that identified and evaluated the risks associated with the various phases of production.  

-    Completed a risk-based facility siting study based on OSHA and American Petroleum Institute (API) recommended practices (RP) guidelines to determine the risk to building occupants from external explosions.  A multi-year program is underway to implement the recommendations from that study.

-    To monitor the overall effectiveness of the facility's PSM programs, Process Safety Metrics are generated each month and reviewed with all units, d

epartments, and Houston Leadership Team.  Identifiable trends receive additional focus and corrective actions.

-    Incident investigations are conducted to identify root causes associated with accidental releases, emergency responses, process safety incidents, etc.  Corrective actions are identified and tracked to resolution.

-    Existing procedures are reviewed and revised on a regular schedule, and new procedures developed as needed to address audit findings, trends in metrics, incident investigations, etc.;

Training

-    Initial training of TXO Leased Workforce operators on the specifics of the process they will be running. Refresher training is supplied at least every three years, and more often as deemed necessary in consultation with TXO operators.

-    An extensive apprenticeship training program for new TXO Leased Workforce operators, which is registered with the U.S. Department of Labor.  WLC has established a working agreement with a local trade school to help train its maintenance personnel. 

-    OSHA training and site-specific contractor safety and health orientation of contract employees prior to performing work within the Sabine Industrial District.



As noted above, WLC has qualified for the federal OSHA Voluntary Protection Program.  VPP is a cooperative program between employers and OSHA to improve worker safety and recognize outstanding safety performance and programs.  WLC has been designated a Star Site.  The Star Program is designed for exemplary worksites with comprehensive, successful safety and health management systems. Companies in the Star Program have achieved injury and illness rates at or below the national average of their respective industries. OSHA has determined that Star sites are self-sufficient in their ability to control workplace hazards. OSHA reviews incident rates annually and reevaluates Star program participants every three to five years. WLC had its most recent VPP Star reevaluation in May 2019.



IV. Five Year Accident Histor

y



In the five years previous to the submission of this report, WLC has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases.  Westlake reviewed its five-year accident history between January 1, 2014 and December 31, 2018 for accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage from covered processes.  One accidental release of 10-100 lbs of ethylene occurred in April 2018.  The release resulted in one non-fatal onsite injury, but no equipment was damaged and no offsite response was necessary.  Westlake revised procedures related to the identified issues to reduce the potential for recurrence. The incident did not result and could not have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of regulated substances; therefore, an incident investigation under 40 CFR ?68.81 was not required.



V. Emergency Response Program



As described in WLC procedure WLC-H&S-017 Site Emergency Plan, for emergencies defined as non-routine incidents that do or can result in damage to property or the environment, serious injury to personnel, evacuation, or extensive disruption to production (such as fires, explosions, gas leaks, spills, injuries requiring an ambulance, and disruption of critical utilities) TXO provides the incident commander and emergency response team and establishes an Emergency Operations Center. Coordination between WLC and TXO is also described in this procedure.  Initial incident reports are directed to Plant Protection, TXO. The Plant Protection guard receiving the call notifies emergency response services and WLC representatives as outlined in the TXO comprehensive site emergency response plan.  



Key elements of the emergency response plan as it relates to community emergency response include, but are not limited to, the following: 

-    TXO maintains an emergency response team whose m

embers are specially trained and equipped to respond to all types of emergencies such as leaks, spills, and fires.

-    TXO emergency response personnel use a computerized modeling system to predict the concentration and location of any vapor cloud resulting from a hazardous vapor release using real time weather information.

-    Response is coordinated with emergency response agencies in the community via an Incident Command Post and the TXO emergency operations center.

-    TXO maintains a community emergency notification plan. For events that might impact the community, a direct line to the City of Longview dispatcher is utilized. The dispatcher contacts the Gregg County Sheriff's office and Harrison County Sheriff's office.

-    Emergency response personnel are regularly trained to comply with all federal, state, and local requirements.

-    An automated community telephone emergency notification system, "Code Red", is available to provide quick, concise emergency information to near neighbors of the Sabine Industrial District if an event were to occur that could affect them.

-    TXO serves on and gives significant support to both the Gregg County and the Harrison County LEPCs.

-    TXO hosts the Northeast Texas Fire School where local municipal and volunteer firefighters from throughout the area receive both classroom and hands-on training for hazardous materials response.



VI. Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Improvement plans fall into four primary areas:



Hazard Analysis - Continual identification of potential hazards, and prompt implementation of corrective action are done in accordance with applicable regulations and as a matter of company policy.



Incident Investigation - Prompt, thorough investigation of all significant incidents and near-misses are conducted and findings are shared across both companies.



Compliance Audits -Periodic audits are conducted at operating areas and with contractors, to ensure compliance with Westlake's safety practices.
